Introduction to Advanced Java What is Advanced Java? Advanced Java refers to the set of advanced topics and APIs used to build enterprise-level, network-based, and web-based applications. It builds on the foundation of Core Java and focuses more on server-side development.
Difference Between Core Java and Advanced Java Feature Core Java Advanced Java Scope Basic language features Advanced web and enterprise features Application Type Standalone applications Web, distributed, and enterprise apps Key APIs OOP, Collections, Threads JDBC, Servlet, JSP, RMI, Socket Examples Desktop apps, tools E-commerce, banking systems, portals Key Components of Advanced Java JDBC (Java Database Connectivity)
API for connecting and executing queries with databases.
Used for CRUD operations.
Works with SQL databases like MySQL, Oracle, PostgreSQL.
Servlets
Java programs that run on a server.
Handle client requests and generate responses.
Lifecycle: init(), service(), destroy().
JSP (JavaServer Pages)
HTML pages with Java code embedded.
Easier than Servlets for building dynamic web pages.
Uses tags and scripting elements.
JavaBeans
Reusable software components.
Follows standard conventions: private properties, getters/setters, no-arg constructor.
RMI (Remote Method Invocation)
Allows Java programs to invoke methods on an object running in another JVM.
Used for distributed applications.
Socket Programming
Enables communication between machines over a network.
Useful for creating chat applications, online games, etc.
Hibernate (Optional but Common)
ORM (Object Relational Mapping) tool for database operations.
Maps Java objects to database tables.
Spring Framework (Optional but Popular)
Framework for enterprise-level Java apps.
Modules: Spring Core, Spring MVC, Spring Boot, etc.
